post_text: Cleburne County Schools joins Jacksonville State University School of Education in congratulating Mr. Corey Cochran! Mr. Cochran is the JSU Instructional Technology SoE Alumni Hall of Fame inductee!
shared_text:
Jacksonville State University - School of Education
May 21 at 1:34 PM ·

Join us in congratulating Mr. Corey Cochran! Mr. Cochran is our Instructional Technology SoE Alumni Hall of Fame inductee!

#JSUStrong
#gamecockproud

Mr. Cochran is currently in his third year as Technology Coordinator for Cleburne County Schools. Prior to
this current position, he served as the Network Administrator for Talladega County Schools for 18 years.

He obtained the Bachelor of Science degree in Computer Information Systems from Jacksonville State University in 1997 and after 20 years, returned to JSU to obtain a Masters of
Science in Instructional Technology. He has also earned the certified Chief Technology Officer designation from the Alabama Leaders in Educational Technology Association and was recently inducted into the Phi Kappa Phi Honor Society at Jacksonville State University.

"By obtaining my Masters in Instructional Technology, I was able to blend both the technical knowledge obtained from my B.S. in CIS and the educational experiences of my technology coordinator roles. The quality expectations and varied array of content exposure gained from the Instructional Technology degree have allowed me to better understand the teachers’instructional needs and assist with the development of plans to expand technology integration into the learning experiences for future generations.
During my tenure at Cleburne County Schools, the district has been able to double the number of students participating in the JSU Technology Fair and obtained over $50,000 in grants to
provide STEM (Science, Technology, Engineering, Mathematics) programs for our middle school students with plans to expand these initiatives to our high schools. Much of the research
and studies during my pursuit of my Masters built the basis for my being able to support the school district in these expanded opportunities.

I would like to thank everyone who supported me throughout the challenges of working full-time, being an on-demand first responder, as well as being a parent and husband. I will say it was
not easy returning to school after 20 years, but with the support of my family and friends, I was able to accomplish a goal never imagined when I first entered JSU in 1993. Being nominated
for the honor of induction into the JSU School of Education Alumni Hall of Fame is extremely humbling."

Corey is married to Casey Cox Cochran, also a JSU graduate and a kindergarten teacher at Cleburne County Elementary School. They have two children, Aidan 13, and Peyton, 9.

NOTES FROM YOUR SCHOOL NURSE

The winter month are upon us, and with that come coughs, colds, flu, and many other illnesses. Here are just a few reminders for you for the upcoming months.

Please remember that if your child has an oral temperature over 100 degrees F., he or she is considered too ill to be in a school environment. Any student who has suffered an illness accompanied with fever should be fever free for 24 hours without the aid of Tylenol, ibuprofen, or other fever reducing medications. Taking medications to lower the temperature to normal and sending your child to the school environment to infect others is not acceptable.

Viruses can also be a problem this time of year. If your child has nausea with vomiting and diarrhea, he or she is considered too ill to be at school. Your child may return to school when he or she has had no vomiting or diarrhea for 24 hours.
Please remind your child to wash his/her hands frequently, especially after coughing, sneezing, or wiping the nose.

Thank you

Sandra McLeroy RN
Lead Nurse
Cleburne County Schools

Dear Cleburne County Schools Alumni,

What a great opportunity to have attended and graduated from either Ranburne High School or Cleburne County High School! For over 250 years, the administrators, faculty, and staff have been preparing students for success in college and careers. I’d like to inform you of a new feature that is being added to the Cleburne County Schools website and other social media. In an effort to highlight the successes of our alumni, we’d like to hear from you. Please complete the attached questionnaire about your experience in our school system and about your life after high school. Your profile may be chosen to appear in a special section for alumni on our system’s website, social media, and/or The Cleburne News. You may submit your own information or you may nominate another alumni. I’d like to include a photo with your profile. You may send your photo and information to Ricketta Wilson, Cleburne County Middle School Library Media Specialist. She will be managing this new feature along with Corey Cochran, Technology Coordinator. You may email us at rwilson@cleburneschools.net, corey.cochran@cleburneschools.net, or cyoung@cleburneschools.net. Please consider contacting us on your own behalf or nominating someone else. You can email the name of a graduate and we will be in touch with them. Include any mailing information that you may have in your email. We appreciate your time and wish you continued success. Cleburne County Schools are among the best in the state and we look forward to sharing your accomplishments.

Online submission form: https://docs.google.com/forms/d/e/1FAIpQLSfPwivoltjntPr9Cp-vCtOX15A-lpeHHGBvpgBmD041QdKzaA/viewform?usp=sf_link

Sincerely,

Chad Young
Cleburne County Board of Education Superintendent

text:
Dear Cleburne County Schools Alumni,

What a great opportunity to have attended and graduated from either Ranburne High School or Cleburne County High School! For over 250 years, the administrators, faculty, and staff have been preparing students for success in college and careers. I’d like to inform you of a new feature that is being added to the Cleburne County Schools website and other social media. In an effort to highlight the successes of our alumni, we’d like to hear from you. Please complete the attached questionnaire about your experience in our school system and about your life after high school. Your profile may be chosen to appear in a special section for alumni on our system’s website, social media, and/or The Cleburne News. You may submit your own information or you may nominate another alumni. I’d like to include a photo with your profile. You may send your photo and information to Ricketta Wilson, Cleburne County Middle School Library Media Specialist. She will be managing this new feature along with Corey Cochran, Technology Coordinator. You may email us at rwilson@cleburneschools.net, corey.cochran@cleburneschools.net, or cyoung@cleburneschools.net. Please consider contacting us on your own behalf or nominating someone else. You can email the name of a graduate and we will be in touch with them. Include any mailing information that you may have in your email. We appreciate your time and wish you continued success. Cleburne County Schools are among the best in the state and we look forward to sharing your accomplishments.

Online submission form: https://docs.google.com/forms/d/e/1FAIpQLSfPwivoltjntPr9Cp-vCtOX15A-lpeHHGBvpgBmD041QdKzaA/viewform?usp=sf_link

Sincerely,

Chad Young
Cleburne County Board of Education Superintendent

Even 4 Education!

Be on the lookout for local businesses participating during the month of December. Help support our schools and children!

How does E4E work? (E4E)
When a purchase is made during an E4E month, the cashier will
tell the customer the total as usual. Next, the cashier will ask if
they would like to make it an even amount for E4E. If yes is the
answer, the change that makes it an even dollar purchase will be
set-aside and will be sent to the Cleburne Count Board of
Education. If the answer is no, the customer will receive their
change as usual.

At the end of the campaign month, the business will send a check to the Cleburne County Board of Education. The people of
Cleburne County will be periodically updated on the progress,
benefits, and use of the E4E money across the whole school
system.

Even For Education starts December 1!

What is Even 4 Education?(E4E)
E4E is your way of helping provide what every child in Cleburne County deserves - the best facilities, opportunities, and education offered in the United States of America. When you say YES to E4E, you have contributed to educating the children of our great county.

Why Even 4 Education?(E4E)
Because it is time that the answer “We do not have enough money” becomes a thing of the past. Cleburne County Schools have always been asked to do more with less and we are proud of what we have accomplished in the past. Our vision is to supplement our schools and students to achieve EVEN more with EVEN 4.

Who?
Participating businesses will allow ALL consumers to donate their change to help us change student lives. Consumers will be ASKED if they want to make their purchase EVEN ($) for Education. (Example: A $3.60 purchase can be an even $4.00 upon approval of the customer. The extra $.40 will go straight to the children of Cleburne County Schools).

Note: If your business would like to participate in the E4E program, please contact the board office at (256) 463-5624.

Chiquita Marbury Technology Innovation Award (Technology Coordinator)

The focus of the Chiquita Marbury Technology Innovation Award is to spotlight K-12 educators, administrators, and support personnel. The award, sponsored by the Alabama Department of Education, honors Chiquita Marbury’s invaluable years of service as a technology innovator in Alabama by recognizing educators who are exemplary models of technology teachers and leaders.

Each year one state award is presented in each of the following categories:
1) Elementary School Teacher
2) Middle School Teacher
3) High School Teacher
4) School Administrator
5) District Technology Coordinator
6) Superintendent/Central Office Staff

Nominees are judged based upon the following five criteria: Innovation and Creativity, Impact on Teaching and Learning, Leadership, Teamwork, and Scholarship.

The 2017 District Technology Coordinator Winner of the Chiquita Marbury Technology Innovation Award is Shawn Hudgins, Cleburne County Schools.

We are proud he is part of the Cleburne County family!

post_text: A big day for CCHS and RHS 8th graders- they went to the Eastman World Of Work (Career Expo). It wasn't you typical career fair. It was all hands on - students got lay to brick, operate robots, repair electrical lines, drive a fork lift, perform surgery on dummies, and so many more activities! They learned about the education or skills needed and the salary for each job.
